item.title: In 2017, a settlement network powered by blockchain announced that it would waive fees for transfers to Singapore
item.description:
OKLink, a global settlement platform, has introduced the first entirely free remittance corridor. The company stated that transfers up to US$100,000 each month to Singapore will be free throughout 2017. Previously, OKLink applied a 0.1% fee on cross-border payments to Singapore, while other companies might charge up to US$5 per transaction. “As the world’s largest blockchain-powered global settlement network, we can process cross-border payments faster and more affordably as more partners join,” explained Jack Liu, Chief Strategy Officer at OKLink...

item.title: Globebill is establishing a payment and bank card settlement system in Saudi Arabia
item.description:
Globebill, a global online payment company, has partnered with Saudi Arabia to establish cross-border trade settlement services. This initiative aligns with China’s “One Belt and One Road” project. Through this partnership, Globebill will introduce a payment and bank card settlement system in Saudi Arabia. This system will issue credit cards to individuals and businesses, facilitating trade between China and Saudi Arabia through Globebill’s platform. Both entities will collaborate to promote Globebill’s payment and settlement services, including the issuance of personal and corporate credit cards across the Middle East and North Africa...

item.title: IP Transit vs Peering vs DIA
item.description:
The internet relies on a complex system of interconnected networks. While it appears as a single entity to users, it’s actually a collection of networks working together to transmit data. At the top are Tier 1 networks, massive international systems with global reach. These networks connect through “peering,” a mutually beneficial arrangement where they exchange traffic equally without fees, effectively expanding their reach. Smaller Tier 2 networks, with limited capacity, can connect to Tier 1 networks for a fee known as “IP transit,” compensating for the traffic imbalance...
